title: Collaborative Games
description: Games that build team bonds, create shared artifacts, and harness collective creativity
philosophy: We are stronger together. Collaborative games reveal that the best solutions emerge from combining diverse perspectives in a spirit of play.

games.name: Agent Trading Cards
games.purpose: Design AI agents as collectible trading cards with stats, abilities, and lore

team_size_adaptations.small: Each person creates 2-3 cards, all cards discussed
team_size_adaptations.medium: Pairs create cards, then 'card draft' to select team deck
team_size_adaptations.large: Groups create cards by domain, representatives present to plenary

materials: Art supplies or AI image generation access

rules.instructions: Review the trading card template. Each agent gets: Name, Visual, Stats (1-10 scale), Primary Ability, Secondary Ability, Weakness, Lore/Backstory, Synergy (works well with which agents).
rules.facilitator_notes: Show example cards for inspiration. Make it feel like designing game cards.

rules.instructions: What agents does your project need? Think about roles: code helper, reviewer, documenter, tester, explorer, architect, etc. Generate at least 2x more than you'll keep.
rules.facilitator_notes: Encourage creative/unusual agents. 'What if we had an agent that...'

rules.instructions: Create full trading cards for your top agent concepts. Fill out every field. Give them personality!
rules.facilitator_notes: The lore/backstory matters - it reveals what role this agent plays in team mythology.

rules.instructions: Display all cards. Gallery walk - everyone reviews all cards, places votes on their favorites.
rules.facilitator_notes: 3 votes per person. Can vote on your own if you really think it's needed.

rules.instructions: Select your project's 'starter deck' of agents. Consider synergies - which agents work well together?
rules.facilitator_notes: Aim for 4-7 agents. Too many is overwhelming. Quality over quantity.

prompts: What would this agent say if it could introduce itself?
Every great hero has a weakness. What's this agent's Achilles' heel?
Which other agent would this one want to pair with for a legendary combo?
If this agent had a catchphrase, what would it be?
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Compile the final deck. Document each agent's complete card. Identify synergy pairs. Note which agent types were most popular (reveals team priorities). Create an 'agent roster' summary.
follow_up_questions: Which agents are essential vs. nice-to-have?
Do we have gaps in our agent roster?
Which agent are you most excited to work with?
How will these agents embody Axiom 0 (Love and Trust)?

success_indicators: Cards feel like real personalities, not just functions
Team is excited about their agent roster

variations.name: Villain Cards
variations.description: Also create 'villain' cards for common problems (tech debt, scope creep, merge conflicts). Agents battle villains!
variations.when_to_use: When the team wants to gamify their development challenges

variations.name: Evolution Cards
variations.description: Agents can 'evolve' into more powerful versions. Design evolution paths.
variations.when_to_use: For longer-term projects where agents will grow in capability

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Creating agents as characters builds love for our tools. Designing their weaknesses requires trust that imperfection is okay.

games.name: Skill Bingo
games.purpose: Identify needed skills through competitive pattern completion

team_size_adaptations.small: Individual bingo cards, shared skill pool
team_size_adaptations.medium: Team bingo (2-3 teams), collaborative card filling

rules.instructions: Fill your bingo card with skills your project might need. Use the skill catalog for inspiration, but add your own too. Each square = one skill.
rules.facilitator_notes: Encourage a mix of obvious and non-obvious skills. 'What skill would be a game-changer?'

rules.instructions: AI facilitator calls out skills one by one. If you have that skill on your card AND can explain why your project needs it, you can mark it.
rules.facilitator_notes: The explanation is key - prevents random skill accumulation.

rules.instructions: First to complete a row, column, or diagonal calls 'Bingo!' and must present their winning skill combination.
rules.facilitator_notes: The combination should make sense as a workflow or capability.

rules.instructions: Review all cards. What skills appeared on multiple cards? What unique skills were included? Build the master skill list.
rules.facilitator_notes: Frequency = importance. Unique entries = hidden needs.

prompts: Skill: [name]. Who has this? And why would your project need it?
Wild card! Add any skill you wish you had on your card. What would it be?
If you could only keep 5 skills from your card, which would they be?
What skill combination would be unbeatable for your project?
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Tally skill frequency across all cards. Identify the 'must-have' skills (>50% of cards). Note unique skills and their rationale. Create prioritized skill list.
follow_up_questions: What skills appeared that surprised you?
What essential skill was missing from most cards?
Which skills should be combined into workflows?
What's the minimum skill set to be effective?

examples: [Domain-specific skills to be added by team]

success_indicators: Team identifies skills beyond the obvious

variations.name: Anti-Skill Bingo
variations.description: Fill cards with skills you DON'T want or need. Avoid getting bingo!
variations.when_to_use: When the team needs to focus and say 'no' to distractions

variations.name: Dream Team Bingo
variations.description: Each square is an agent-skill combination. Build your dream team.
variations.when_to_use: After Agent Trading Cards, to assign skills to agents

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Everyone's skill suggestions are valued - trust in collective wisdom. Love for the work shows in wanting the best tools.

games.name: Architecture Pictionary
games.purpose: Surface mental models of system architecture through visual communication

team_size_adaptations.small: Round-robin drawing, all participate in guessing
team_size_adaptations.medium: Two teams alternate drawing and guessing
team_size_adaptations.large: Multiple parallel games, then compare diagrams

rules.instructions: Generate concepts to draw: components, patterns, data flows, integrations. Write each on a card/note. Mix technical and abstract concepts.
rules.facilitator_notes: Include both obvious (database, API) and abstract (authentication flow, error handling).

rules.instructions: Drawer picks a concept, has 60 seconds to draw while others guess. No words, letters, or numbers in drawings!
rules.facilitator_notes: Embrace imperfection! Stick figures are fine. Speed matters.

rules.instructions: For concepts that were drawn multiple times, compare drawings. Did everyone visualize it the same way?
rules.facilitator_notes: Differences reveal different mental models - this is gold!

rules.instructions: Collaboratively create a 'canonical' diagram combining the best elements from all drawings.
rules.facilitator_notes: This becomes an actual artifact. Make it clean enough to reference later.

prompts: Draw: The data flow when a user submits a form
Draw: How authentication works in our system
Draw: Where errors get caught and handled
Draw: How our agents will collaborate
Draw: The relationship between frontend and backend
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Photograph/save all drawings. Note where mental models aligned vs. diverged. Identify concepts that were easy to visualize (well-understood) vs. hard (needs clarity). Compile canonical diagrams.
follow_up_questions: Which concept was hardest to draw? What does that tell us?
Where did our mental models differ most?
What's missing from our canonical diagram?
How should we document this architecture going forward?

success_indicators: Everyone can 'see' the system more clearly

variations.name: Progressive Pictionary
variations.description: One person starts, next person adds to the drawing, and so on. Final result is collaborative.
variations.when_to_use: When you want to build shared ownership of diagrams

variations.name: Blind Pictionary
variations.description: Describer can only use words, drawer can only draw. Tests communication clarity.

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Sharing imperfect drawings requires trust - we won't judge each other's art skills. Love for clarity drives us to communicate visually.

games.name: Demo Derby
games.purpose: Celebrate and showcase what the team created during the workshop series

team_size_adaptations.small: Each person demos one artifact they're proud of
team_size_adaptations.medium: Sub-groups demo their contributions, all celebrate together
team_size_adaptations.large: Representative demos with audience participation awards

rules.instructions: List all artifacts created during the workshop series: Team Charter, Ethics Framework, Agent Cards, Skill List, Architecture Diagrams, etc.
rules.facilitator_notes: Be thorough! Every artifact represents team effort.

rules.instructions: Each person/group signs up to present one artifact. Choose something you're proud of or that you think is especially important.
rules.facilitator_notes: Ensure all major artifacts are covered.

rules.instructions: 2-3 minutes per demo. Present what it is, why it matters, and what you learned creating it. Audience cheers!
rules.facilitator_notes: Keep energy high. Applause after each demo. This is celebration!

rules.instructions: Award fun prizes: Most Creative, Most Impactful, Best Team Effort, etc. Everyone should be recognized.
rules.facilitator_notes: The awards are for fun. Make them silly and memorable.

rules.instructions: AI facilitator shows how all artifacts will be integrated into the final Cursor agent system.
rules.facilitator_notes: Connect the fun back to the practical outcome.

prompts: What's the story behind this artifact? What discussion led to it?
If you could change one thing about this artifact, what would it be?
How does this artifact embody our team's values?
What surprised you while creating this?
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Document all demos. Capture key quotes and stories. Compile 'workshop journey' narrative. Prepare artifacts for integration into generated system.
follow_up_questions: What artifact are you most proud of as a team?
What did you learn about your teammates during this process?
How will these artifacts guide your daily work?
What would you do differently if we did this again?

success_indicators: Team feels proud of collective work
All artifacts are reviewed and validated
Team is excited for next steps

variations.name: External Demo
variations.description: Invite stakeholders or leadership to watch the Demo Derby
variations.when_to_use: When stakeholder buy-in is needed or desired

variations.name: Virtual Demo Derby
variations.description: Async artifact submissions, sync celebration call

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Celebration is an act of love - acknowledging everyone's contribution. Sharing our work openly demonstrates trust in each other's reactions.

games.name: Gratitude Circle
games.purpose: Close the workshop series with appreciation and connection

team_size_adaptations.small: Full circle, everyone speaks to everyone
team_size_adaptations.medium: Paired gratitudes, then share highlights with group
team_size_adaptations.large: Written gratitudes shared anonymously, readings in plenary

rules.instructions: Gather in a circle. Take a breath. Reflect on the journey we've taken together.
rules.facilitator_notes: Create quiet, reflective atmosphere. Transition from celebration energy.

rules.instructions: Think of one specific moment when someone on this team helped you, taught you, or inspired you. What did they do? How did it impact you?
rules.facilitator_notes: Specificity matters. 'When you said X, I felt Y' is better than 'thanks for everything'.

rules.instructions: Go around the circle. Each person expresses gratitude to one (or more) team members. Specific is better than general.
rules.facilitator_notes: No pressure to be profound. Authentic is better than polished.

rules.instructions: AI facilitator offers closing reflection on the team's journey. A moment of silence to appreciate what we've built together.
rules.facilitator_notes: This is the emotional capstone. Let it breathe.

prompts: As I witnessed your journey, I saw [specific observation about team growth].
What you've created together reflects genuine care for each other and for the people you'll serve.
The [artifact/moment] showed me [insight about team character].
Carry this spirit of love and trust into your work together.
ai_facilitation.synthesis_instructions: Capture the essence of gratitudes shared (with permission). Document themes of appreciation. Create 'team gratitude summary' as a keepsake artifact.

success_indicators: Team feels closer than when they started
Positive energy for the work ahead

variations.name: Gratitude Letters
variations.description: Each person writes a letter to the team, read aloud or shared later
variations.when_to_use: When you want a permanent keepsake

variations.name: Appreciation Avalanche
variations.description: One person in the 'hot seat' while everyone else shares what they appreciate about them
variations.when_to_use: For smaller teams, more intimate settings

games.connection_to_axiom_zero: Gratitude is love expressed. Sharing appreciation vulnerably builds deep trust. This practice embodies Axiom 0 completely.
